contentrichtext.text: {{for|the census-designated place|Esparto, California}} {{stack begin}} {{taxobox |name = Esparto Grass |image = Stipa tenacissima.jpg |regnum = [[Plantae]] |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Monocots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Commelinids]] |ordo = [[Poales]] |familia = [[Poaceae]] |genus = ''[[Macrochloa]]'' |species = '''''M. tenacissima''''' |binomial = ''Macrochloa tenacissima'' |binomial_authority = ([[Carolus Linnaeus|L.]]) Kunth. |synonyms = ''Stipa tenacissima'' <small>L.</small> |}} [[File:Esparto.jpg|thumb|200px|Esparto ready for crafts]] {{stack end}} '''Esparto''', or '''esparto grass''', also known as "halfah (alpha/alfa) grass" or "needle grass", '''''Macrochloa tenacissima''''', is a perennial [[grass]] grown in northwest [[Africa]] and the southern part of the [[Iberian Peninsula]] employed for crafts ([[Rope|cords]], [[basket]]s, [[espadrilles]], etc.). ==Esparto paper== [[File:Pleita artesania esparto.jpg|thumb|left|Woven esparto]] It is used for [[fiber]] production for [[paper]] making. The fiber makes a high quality paper often used in [[book]] manufacturing. First used in [[Great Britain]] in 1850, it has been extensively used there and in [[Europe]], but is rarely found in the [[United States]] because of the cost of transport. It is usually combined with five to ten percent [[wood pulp]]. The "Spanish" grade is usually regarded as the higher-quality, while the "Tripoli" grade, from Africa, is the lesser in quality. The fibers are fairly short in relation to their width, yet do not create any significant amount of dust. Because of the short fiber length, the tensile strength of the paper is less than that of many other papers, but its resistance to shrinkage and stretching is superior, and the paper is a well-filled, dense paper with excellent inking qualities. It also has very good folding properties. ''[[Lygeum]] spartum'', another species of grass, is also used in combination with true esparto, and is also sometimes called "esparto grass" or [[albardine]]. Some manufacturers of [[rolling paper]] may use esparto, which might lead to a slightly higher carcinogen level when burned. [http://www.amat.es/convenio/circulares/2003/DICIEMBRE/CIRCULAR%20N%C2%BA%20114-03/Circular%20n%C2%BA%20114-03.pdf]. ==Related terms== *[[Espartinas]], a town in the province of Seville, Spain *The family name [[Espartero]] means "esparto worker or seller". *Atocha is another Spanish word for "esparto". ==External links== *{{commons-inline|Stipa tenacissima}} *{{wikispecies-inline|Stipa tenacissima}} *[http://cameo.mfa.org/browse/record.asp?subkey=3444 Esparto as a material] *[http://www.regmurcia.com/servlet/s.Sl?sit=c,96,m,918&r=ReP-928-DETALLE_REPORTAJES Esparto Museum] {{es}} *[http://www.esparte.es/ Esparto fine craftsmanship] {{es}} *[http://en.scientificcommons.org/32420914 European influence and tribal society in Tunisia during the nineteenth century: the origins and impact of the trade in esparto grass 1870-1940.
